Picture this: A global pandemic hits, economies are forced to shut down, unemployment rates soar, and businesses are struggling to survive. The world is in chaos and leaders are scrambling for answers. Where do they turn?
The answer: The G20. The Group of Twenty (G20) is an international forum of the world's leading economies that was founded in 1999 in the wake of the Asian financial crisis. Its members represent roughly two-thirds of the world's population, 80% of global trade, and 85% of global GDP. The G20 plays a crucial role in global politics, particularly in times of crises.
India is set to assume the presidency of the G20 in 2022. This is a crucial role for the country, as it will give India the opportunity to lead the agenda of the world's most powerful economies. India's priorities for its presidency include building a resilient future, promoting sustainable development, and fostering innovation. In addition to these priorities, India will also be focused on addressing the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the global economy and ensuring equitable access to vaccines.
The G20 has proven to be an essential forum for global leaders to come together and address major issues facing the world. We have seen the group play a crucial role in past crises, and its role in the COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted its importance once again. India's presidency of the G20 in 2022 will be a unique opportunity for the country to lead the world in building a more resilient and sustainable future.

Cricket is a game of uncertainties and surprises. One minute a team can be cruising to victory, and the next they can be staring down the barrel of defeat. This was the case for India in the World Test Championship final against Australia, where their top order collapsed in spectacular fashion.
India started the day on 146-3, with captain Virat Kohli and vice-captain Ajinkya Rahane at the crease. However, within the space of two overs, India lost both Kohli and Rahane, as well as Cheteshwar Pujara and Rishabh Pant. It was a stunning display of bowling from the Australians, who exploited the difficult conditions to perfection.
India's collapse was reminiscent of similar collapses in other matches, where teams have been cruising at one point, only to suddenly crumble under pressure. One such match was the Ashes Test between England and Australia in 2019, where England lost 8 wickets for just 63 runs, despite being in a dominant position earlier in the innings.
Another example is the India vs New Zealand Test in 2020, where India collapsed from 194-4 to 242 all out, losing 6 wickets for just 48 runs. This collapse cost India the match, as New Zealand went on to win by 10 wickets.
In this match, England were in a strong position, trailing by just 82 runs on the first innings with 4 wickets in hand. However, a sudden collapse saw them lose 8 wickets for just 63 runs, with Stuart Broad taking 5 wickets for just 17 runs. This collapse proved pivotal, as Australia went on to win the match by 185 runs.

In 2008, India's relations with its eastern neighbor, Bangladesh, were at an all-time low. The Bangladeshi government, led by the Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP), had been unresponsive to India's pleas for greater cooperation on issues such as cross-border terrorism, smuggling, and illegal immigration. The situation was further complicated by the presence of several militant groups in Bangladesh that were hostile to India.
Then, in December of that year, Bangladesh held parliamentary elections, and the Awami League emerged as the victor. The party, which had close ties to India, immediately began to take measures that addressed India's concerns. Within weeks of taking office, the Awami League launched a crackdown on militant groups, resulting in the arrest of many top leaders.
Since then, India-Bangladesh relations have improved significantly. The two countries have signed multiple important agreements, including the Land Boundary Agreement (LBA), which resolved a long-standing border dispute, and a transit agreement that gives India access to Bangladeshi ports. India is now Bangladesh's largest trading partner, and there is extensive cooperation on issues such as counter-terrorism, energy, and connectivity.
One of the key challenges India faces is securing its borders with Bangladesh, which is over 4,000 km long. Before the Awami League came to power, there was little cooperation between the two countries on this issue. However, since then, there have been significant improvements. For example, a Joint Border Working Group was established to enhance coordination between the border forces of both countries. In 2015, a new border management agreement was signed, which has helped reduce border incidents and smuggling.
Another area of cooperation between India and Bangladesh is in connectivity. In 2016, the two countries signed a landmark agreement to establish a coastal shipping service, which has significantly reduced the time and cost of transporting goods between them. India is also working with Bangladesh on several major infrastructure projects, including a rail link that will connect the two countries. These initiatives will help boost trade and investment, create jobs, and improve the quality of life for millions of people.

Once upon a time, in the beautiful Pacific Island countries, people lived simple and peaceful lives. However, things started to change when a new player entered the game - China. The big brother from the north came with a bag full of promises - infrastructure development, economic growth, and unlimited opportunities. The island nations were thrilled and welcomed their new friend with open arms.
However, as time passed, the fine print in the agreement started to show its true colors. The Chinese projects turned out to be massive debt traps, leaving the small countries at the mercy of their newfound master. The promises of growth and development turned into nightmares of imbalance and dependency. The locals saw their resources being exploited while their cultural heritage was being erased.
Meanwhile, some distant countries were watching all this unfold from afar. They were concerned about the implications of an assertive China in the Pacific region. They knew they had to act fast before it was too late. Among these countries, India emerged as a prominent contender to provide an alternative to Chinese influence.
The Pacific Island countries are no strangers to power games played by bigger players. However, the Chinese approach has been particularly aggressive and strategic in recent years. Take, for instance, the case of Vanuatu - a small island nation with a population of around 300,000. China has established a military base in the country, giving it a strategic advantage over other players in the Pacific region. Similarly, in Fiji, China has made significant investments in infrastructure projects, including the construction of government buildings and sports venues.
However, there is growing concern among the locals about the implications of Chinese investment. They fear that their natural resources, such as timber and fisheries, are being exploited for the benefit of Chinese companies and could lead to ecological disasters. Moreover, China's presence is viewed as a threat to the island nations' sovereignty, as it could lead to increased political meddling and control.

Imagine a country sharing its borders with another country that has repeatedly shown aggressive posturing through military build-up, territorial incursions, and expansionist policies. Now, imagine that the country decides to take a bold move to counter such aggression and protect its sovereignty and security. This hypothetical scenario is a grim reality for India, which has been facing such a threat from its neighbor China.
In recent years, China's assertiveness in the region has increased manifold, and its intrusion into the Indian territory across the Line of Actual Control (LAC) has become a cause of concern for India. In this context, India's move to construct a strategic road to the right side of the Pangong Lake near the LAC with China is a significant step towards ensuring its security and safeguarding its territorial integrity.
Pangong Lake is a glacial lake located in the Himalayas at an altitude of around 4,350 meters. It is 134 km long and is bifurcated by the LAC, with one-third of it falling in India's territory and two-thirds in China's. The lake has witnessed several border standoffs between Indian and Chinese troops, with the most recent one being in August 2020, when China tried to change the status quo in the area.
The strategic road being constructed by India will run along the Pangong Tso lake's northern bank, from Thakung to Chusul. This will provide easier access for the Indian military to patrol the area and keep a check on any Chinese misadventure in the region. The road will also improve connectivity in the area, which is crucial for India's border management and defense preparedness. The move is seen as a significant strategic shift as earlier, India's infrastructure development was mostly limited to the western sector.

India and its neighbors have been maintaining a cooperative and friendly relationship to promote regional development and stability in recent years. As part of this initiative, India recently announced its decision to host the virtual Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) summit in 2020. This is an unprecedented move that sends the right signals to the region that cooperation and collaboration are essential for long-term security and prosperity.
The SCO is a regional organization comprising eight members, including China, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Russia, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, India and Pakistan. The organization was formed in 2001 with the aim of promoting cooperation in political, economic, and security matters among member states. India, as an observer since 2005, became a full member in 2017.
India's decision to host the virtual SCO summit amid the Covid-19 crisis, when physical meetings have become difficult, is a testimony to the country's commitment to regional cooperation. The virtual format will enable leaders to discuss critical issues related to regional security, economic cooperation, and people-to-people ties while maintaining social distancing. It is also an important step towards making the SCO more efficient, effective, and responsive to the needs of member states.
A case in point is India's proposal to create a working group on traditional medicine within the SCO framework, which was welcomed by all member states. This initiative reflects India's traditional knowledge in the field of medicine and its commitment to promoting cross-border cooperation to harness the benefits of traditional medicine for the well-being of people in the region.

When it comes to international trade, tariffs can be a major point of contention. That's currently the case between India and the United States, as India has requested an exemption from US tariffs on steel and aluminium. India has proposed removing some tariffs on US agricultural goods in exchange, but the US has shown little interest in the offer.
This situation is a prime example of the complexities and challenges involved in international trade negotiations. Let's take a closer look at the issue and its potential impacts.
In March 2018, the United States announced tariffs of 25% and 10% on imported steel and aluminium, respectively. These tariffs apply to imports from all countries, including India. Since then, India has been seeking an exemption from the tariffs, citing significant impacts on its export ability and domestic steel and aluminium industries.
India has proposed a solution in which it would remove some tariffs on imported US agricultural goods, giving US farmers greater export access to the Indian market. While the proposal has been raised in discussions between the two countries, the US has yet to seriously consider the idea.
If India is unable to secure an exemption from US steel and aluminium tariffs, it could experience a major blow to its export industry. The country is a significant exporter of steel and aluminium, with India accounting for about 2% of the US steel market, according to the International Trade Administration. India has already seen a decline in steel exports to the US since the tariffs were put in place.

The latest example of this is the Indian government's decision to allow the Pakistan football team to participate in the South Asian Football Federation (SAFF) Cup, slated to take place in Bengaluru from June 21 to July 4. Sports diplomacy is the use of sporting events and activities to improve cross-cultural understanding and relations between countries. It has been used effectively in the past to strengthen bilateral ties, resolve conflicts and create new opportunities for cooperation.
One of the most famous examples of sports diplomacy is the Unified Korean team that participated in the 2018 Winter Olympics held in Pyeongchang, South Korea. The team consisted of both North and South Korean athletes, and it was formed as a goodwill gesture during a period of heightened tensions between the two countries. The team walked together during the opening ceremony under a unified Korean peninsula flag and played alongside each other in the women's hockey event.

However, the reality is that sport and politics have been intertwined for decades. Politics often plays a role in deciding which countries participate in sporting events or whether a particular team can travel or not. For example, the Pakistani football team was banned from playing in India in 2019. The ban was due to escalating tensions between the two countries, with the Indian government citing security concerns for the decision.
However, this year, a glimmer of hope has emerged. The Indian government has cleared the participation of the Pakistan football team in the upcoming SAFF Cup, as confirmed by the All India Football Federation (AIFF) Secretary. The SAFF Cup is a biennial football competition that features the national teams of South Asian countries.
The decision to allow the Pakistani football team to participate in the SAFF Cup is significant on many levels. Firstly, it represents a positive step towards normalizing relations between India and Pakistan, two nuclear-armed neighbors who have had a strained relationship for many years. The fact that sport is being used to bring people together shows that there are shared values that transcend political differences.
Moreover, this decision provides an opportunity for the Pakistani football team to showcase its talent on an international stage. Football is a popular sport in Pakistan, but the national team has been struggling in recent years. In the last SAFF Cup, held in 2018, Pakistan was knocked out in the group stage without winning a single game. This year's competition, which is set to be held in September, will provide Pakistan with a chance to make a mark and perhaps even win the tournament.

Once upon a time, the Indian rupee was seen as a volatile currency that could swing dramatically in response to global economic events. But that reputation has been changing in recent years, as the country has implemented policies to make the rupee more stable and attractive to foreign investors.
One of the biggest factors contributing to this stability has been the Indian government's efforts to reduce the country's current account deficit. This deficit, which represents the difference between export earnings and import expenses, had been a major concern for investors who worried that it could lead to a depreciation in the rupee's value. However, India has been successful in reducing its current account deficit to around 1% of GDP, down from 5.8% in 2012.
Another important factor has been the steady inflow of foreign funds into India's economy. These funds represent a vote of confidence in India's economic prospects, and have helped to support the value of the rupee. According to the Securities and Exchange Board of India, foreign portfolio investors have pumped around 30 billion USD into the country's stock market in 2021 alone.
Today, the Indian rupee remains stable despite uncertainties elsewhere in the global economy. In fact, on September 8th, it ended mostly flat after the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) kept the key policy rate unchanged, as widely expected. This move was largely discounted by the market, indicating that investors are confident in the stability of the rupee.
Looking ahead, many investors are now turning their attention to the U.S. Federal Reserve rate outcome next week. This event has the potential to impact global currencies, including the rupee. However, experts predict that the rupee will remain stable due to its lower current account deficit and continued foreign fund inflows in the current financial year.

It was a typical early morning in the Amazon rainforest when a group of Indigenous people spotted a group of illegal loggers cutting down trees in their ancestral land. The loggers were armed, but the Indigenous people were determined to protect their forest, their home, their source of life. They stood between the trees and the machines, refusing to back down to the aggressors.
For centuries, Indigenous peoples have been the most committed defenders of the Earth. They have lived in harmony with their surroundings, respecting and protecting the natural resources that sustain life. They have developed a rich knowledge of the flora and fauna, of the soil and the water, of the cycles and the rhythms of the land. They have passed down this knowledge from generation to generation, along with a deep sense of connection to the Earth, a profound spirituality that recognizes the interdependence of all life.
However, the rise of modern civilization has brought about an era of unprecedented environmental destruction, as the pursuit of profit and power has led to the exploitation and degradation of the planet's resources. This destruction has hit the Indigenous peoples the hardest, as their lands and waters have been invaded, polluted, and destroyed by extractive industries, monoculture agriculture, damming and mining projects, and other forms of corporate and state violence.
The defenders of the Earth have become the targets of violence, intimidation, harassment, and persecution, as they resist the forces of destruction and demand respect for their rights, their territories, and their ways of life. They pay a heavy price for their defense, as their communities are threatened, displaced, and decimated, their leaders are jailed, tortured, and killed, and their cultures are eroded, suppressed, and forgotten.
The Indigenous people of the Philippines have been fighting against mining, logging, and other forms of resource exploitation for decades. They have established barricades, roadblocks, and other forms of collective resistance to prevent the entry of mining companies and other extractive industries into their territories. They have also taken legal action to challenge the granting of permits and licenses to these companies, arguing that they violate their constitutional and customary rights.

It is shocking to learn that some individuals in Canada celebrated the assassination of former Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. On October 31, 1984, Gandhi was shot dead by two of her bodyguards, and the news of her demise sent shock waves across the globe. While the majority of people mourned her death, some in Canada responded with obnoxious celebrations. What could be the reason behind such behavior?

One possible cause is the racial tensions that have existed between the Indian and Sikh communities in Canada. The assassination of Gandhi was an act of vengeance for the Indian government's military operation against Sikh militants who had occupied the Golden Temple in Amritsar earlier that year. The operation, known as Operation Blue Star, was regarded by many Sikhs as a brutal attack on their religious shrine, and it led to widespread unrest and violence in the Sikh community. The assassination of Gandhi was seen by some Sikhs in Canada as a justifiable response to the Indian government's actions.

The Reserve Bank of India's latest monetary policy meeting

Now, imagine you are a retail investor in India, looking for opportunities to earn a decent return on your savings. You have been keeping an eye on the RBI's monetary policy meetings, hoping for a rate cut to boost your stock portfolio. But despite the recent drop in CPI inflation, the RBI has chosen a wait-and-watch approach, citing global geopolitical uncertainty and potential El-Nino disruption to food inflation.
Both scenarios highlight the need for caution and prudence in decision-making, especially in a rapidly changing economic environment. It is often said that the only constant in life is change. This holds true in every aspect of our lives, and the financial world is no exception. With the recent RBI policy announcement, investors are set to benefit from the falling interest rate regime. In this article, we will explore how this change will affect investors, provide some examples through case studies, and conclude with 3 points.
Firstly, lower interest rates mean that borrowing becomes cheaper. This makes it an opportune time for businesses to invest in capital upgrades, expansions, and mergers and acquisitions. With easy access to credit and cheaper borrowing costs, businesses are motivated to make investments that accelerate their growth and output. This ultimately leads to higher profitability, which can then be passed onto investors in the form of higher returns.
Secondly, the lower interest rate environment causes bond prices to rise, and this can lead to higher capital appreciation for investors. As bond prices rise, the yield or return on investment decreases. This means that investors are motivated to lock in yields before further drops. With the expectation of further rate cuts, bond investors can anticipate higher returns from their investments.
Thirdly, the lowering of interest rates could lead to increased consumer spending. With lower borrowing costs for households, individuals are encouraged to spend more on big-ticket items like homes and cars, which could stimulate the economy in the longer term. This could be particularly impactful in India, where a large percentage of the population is still underbanked and has limited access to credit.
